titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Phelps Putnam Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:30

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Phelps Putnam papers contain correspondence, writings, and personal papers documenting the life and work of poet Howard Phelps Putnam. Correspondence in the collection features letters with family, Yale college friends, including Russell Cheney, Farwell Knapp, Donald Ogden Stewart, and Charles Walker, and other authors, including Paul Rosenfeld, Allen Tate, and Stark Young. Writings contains drafts for poems and short prose pieces dating from 1914 to the late 1940s. Other materials in the collection include biographical notes, clippings relating to Putnam, a last will, photographs, and a remembrance by his wife Una (Fayerweather) Putnam.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Charles Walker, 1951. Additional gifts and purchases acquired from 1953 to 1977.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Phelps Putnam papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Phelps Putnam Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preliminary processing was done to the Phelps Putnam papers at an unknown date. During reprocessing of the collection in 2010, the arrangement of correspondence and writings was largely preserved in Series I and II, and other materials were consolidated in Series III.

bioghist.head: Howard Phelps Putnam (1894-1948)
bioghist.p: Born in Massachusetts in 1894, Putnam attended Philips Exeter Academy before enrolling at Yale. A member of the secret society Skull and Bones, Putnam has been named among the Renaissance generation at Yale, which includes Stephen Vincent Benét, Henry R. Luce, Archibald MacLeish, Cole Porter, and Thornton Wilder. Following graduation, Putnam traveled to Europe and worked a series of jobs, including a period as an assistant editor for The Atlantic Monthly Press and writing advertising copy for an insurance company. Putnam's first book of poems, Trinc , was published in 1927. Following publication of Trinc , Putnam set to work on an epic, to be titled "The Earthly Comedy," which would recount modern life and feature characters such as Bill Williams and his alter ego Bigelow Hasbrouck. The publication of The Five Seasons (1931) features these characters and marks the beginning of Putnam's work towards producing "The Earthly Comedy". Putnam never completed the work before his death in 1948, however, thwarted perhaps by ill health (asthma and alcoholism) and the paralyzing ambition of his plans. As F.O. Matthiessen acknowledges in his essay "To the Memory of Phelps Putnam," "he sketched a poem too vast ever to be able to shoulder the weight of writing it".
Putnam married twice, to Ruth Peters and Una Fayerweather, and had numerous affairs, including trysts with Katharine Hepburn and painter Russell Cheney.

Summary information on Howard Phelps Putnam taken from an October 2007 description of the Farwell Knapp Papers in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library poetry blog (see http://beineckepoetry.wordpress.com/2007/10/).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Phelps Putnam papers contain correspondence, writings, and personal papers documenting the life and work of poet Howard Phelps Putnam. Correspondence in the collection features letters to and from family, Yale college friends, including Russell Cheney, Farwell Knapp, Donald Ogden Stewart, and Charles Walker, and other authors, including Paul Rosenfeld, Allen Tate, and Stark Young. Writings contains drafts for poems and short prose pieces dating from 1914 to the late 1940s. Other materials in the collection include biographical notes, clippings relating to Putnam, a last will, photographs, and a remembrance by his wife Una (Fayerweather) Putnam.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1915-1951. II. Writings, 1914-1947. III. Personal Papers, 1923-1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence, features correspondence with Yale college friends Russell Cheney, Farwell Knapp, Donald Ogden Stewart, and Charles Walker, and with family and other authors, including Paul Rosenfeld, Allen Tate, and Stark Young.
Unsorted correspondence is located at the end of the alphabetical run.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries, for poetry and prose, and arranged alphabetically by title (in quotes) or supplied heading (in brackets).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, contains drafts, most corrected, for poems and short prose pieces. In additon to the title, physical formats (e.g. "holograph" and "typescript" ) are noted in folder headings below.
Unsorted poems can be found under the supplied heading [Poems] and at the end of the alphabetical run of titles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Personal Papers, includes biographical notes, clippings relating to Putnam, a last will, several photographs, and a remembrance by his wife Una (Fayerweather) Putnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of Phelps and Una Putnam, Bronson Cutting, and others

did.unittitle: "Some Further Notes on Phelps Putnam By His Wife"

did.physloc: Stored in: Oversize, broadside cabinets, container 14
